official-title.#text: To improve health care furnished by the Department of Veterans Affairs and the Department of Defense by increasing access to complementary and alternative medicine and other approaches to wellness and preventive care, and for other purposes.

short-title.#text: Veterans and Armed Forces Health Promotion Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text: Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Defense expansion of research and education into integration of complementary and alternative medicine interventions

header.#text: Medical treatment and research facilities jointly operated by the department of veterans affairs and the department of defense

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the
shall jointly develop and implement a plan to establish jointly-operated medical treatment and research facilities. Such facilities shall—

text.#text: Commencing not later than 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the
and members of the Armed Forces;

text.#text: be staffed by employees of the

by a ratio determined in a memorandum of understanding between the Secretaries; and

text.#text: be operated by dividing the operation and maintenance expenses between both the
bill to each Department the cost of certain specialty medical services, including radiology, laboratory, and surgery, as such services are used.
The pilot program shall be carried out during the three-year period beginning on the date of the commencement of the pilot program.
The Secretaries shall carry out the pilot program by establishing not fewer than 5 joint medical treatment and research facilities.
In selecting locations for the pilot program, the Secretaries shall consider the feasibility and advisability of selecting locations—
in areas with a high concentration of veterans and members of the Armed Forces;
that present a reasonable probability of cost savings to the taxpayer by consolidation of services and facilities currently administered separately as determined jointly by the Secretaries; and
where collaboration of research and treatment will be most beneficial to the common needs of the patients under the care of both Departments, as determined jointly by the Secretaries.

header.#text: Pilot program on transformation of veterans services organizations facilities into veteran health and wellness centers

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall carry out a pilot program under which the Secretary makes grants to nonprofit veterans services organizations (hereinafter in this section referred to as
in accordance with
, to upgrade, through construction and repair, VSO community facilities into health and wellness centers.

text.#text: The

The recipient of a grant under this section shall use the grant to carry out the repair of a facility owned by the recipient or to construct a facility on property owned by the recipient. Such funds may not be used to purchase real estate or to carry out repair of facilities leased by the recipient or to construct facilities on property leased by the recipient. Any facility repaired or constructed using grant funds shall be used to provide alternative medical care, or wellness programs, to veterans and family members as such term is defined in

As a condition of the receipt of a grant under this section, a VSO shall agree to carry out the operation and maintenance of the facility that is repaired or constructed using grant funds for the three-year period beginning on the date of the completion of the repair or construction.
The pilot program shall be carried out during the two-year period beginning on the date of the commencement of the pilot program.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall ensure that the grant recipients use grant funds to construct or repair facilities located in at least ten different geographic locations. The
shall give priority to locations in economically depressed areas that are not in close proximity to
medical centers.
